newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran asks Pakistan to stop attacks on Shi'ites.
newsitem.headline: Iran asks Pakistan to stop attacks on Shi'ites.

text.p: Iran on Thursday urged Pakistan to prevent the assassination of Shi'ites Moslems in Pakistan, the Iranian news agency IRNA said.

It quoted Hassan Rowhani, secretary of Iran's National Security Council, as calling on the Pakistani government to mount a "crackdown on terrorist groups in Pakistan and (prevent) the assassination of Shi'ite Moslems".
He made the remarks in a meeting with visiting Pakistani Foreign Minister Sahibzada Yaqoob Khan.
"The groups not only endanger Pakistan's security but also hamper the unity of Moslems," said Rowhani, a Shi'ite cleric.
Two Shi'ite leaders were killed in separate incidents in Pakistan on December 31 and a Shi'ite activist was gunned down on Monday.
The attacks appeared to be connected to a long-running feud between armed Sunni and Shi'ite groups that cost more than 40 lives last year in Pakistan.
Pakistan is dominated by Sunnis, Islam's majority sect, while Iran is mainly Shi'ite.

Khan earlier discussed the crisis in neighbouring Afghanistan and bilateral ties with Iranian President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, IRNA said. He met Parliament Speaker Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri and Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati on Wednesday.
Iran and Pakistan hold contrasting views of the Taleban Islamic movement, which seized Kabul in September, but have sought to contain their differences by maintaining a dialogue on Afghanistan.
Iran has charged Pakistan with setting up and supporting the Taleban, saying the group is also backed by the United States. Pakistan denies favouring any faction.
Tehran recognises the government of ousted President Burhanuddin Rabbani but it has urged Afghan factions to reach a power-sharing agreement.
